title: PowerShell Debugging Techniques and Tools
body:
PowerShell provides comprehensive debugging capabilities for script and module development:

**Breakpoint Types:**
```powershell
# Line breakpoints
Set-PSBreakpoint -Script "script.ps1" -Line 10

# Command breakpoints
Set-PSBreakpoint -Command "Get-Process"

# Variable breakpoints
Set-PSBreakpoint -Variable "myVar" -Mode Write

# Conditional breakpoints
Set-PSBreakpoint -Script "script.ps1" -Line 5 -Action { if ($count -gt 10) { break } }
```

**Debugger Commands:**
- s (Step Into): Step into functions/cmdlets
- v (Step Over): Execute current line
- o (Step Out): Exit current function
- c (Continue): Resume execution
- q (Quit): Exit debugger
- k (Get-PSCallStack): Show call stack
- ? (Help): Show debugger commands

**Debug Preferences:**
```powershell
# Enable debugging globally
$DebugPreference = "Inquire"  # Prompt on Write-Debug
$DebugPreference = "Continue" # Show debug messages

# Control error debugging
$ErrorActionPreference = "Break"  # Break into debugger on errors
```

**Remote Debugging:**
- Enter-PSSession for remote debugging
- Debug-Runspace for background jobs
- Wait-Debugger for just-in-time debugging

**Script Debugging Best Practices:**
- Use Write-Debug for diagnostic output
- Add strategic breakpoints in complex logic
- Use $PSDebugContext in breakpoint actions
- Test with different execution policies
- Debug with -noprofile to avoid environment issues

**Advanced Debugging:**
```powershell
# Debug background jobs
$job = Start-Job { Get-Process }
Debug-Job $job

# Debug with specific runspace
Get-Runspace | Debug-Runspace

# Custom debugger handlers
Register-ObjectEvent -InputObject $host.Runspace.Debugger -EventName DebuggerStop -Action {
    # Custom debug logic
}
```
